
A voxel, short for "volume element", is the **three-dimensional (3D) equivalent of a pixel** in two dimensions (2D). It represents a value on a regular grid in 3D space. Just as a pixel represents 2D image data, a voxel represents volume data or 3D data.


![What is a voxel? - Mega Voxels](data:image/jpeg;base64,)


In terms of graphics and visualization, voxels are often used to represent **3D objects** and environments in video games and other simulations. They can be used to build complex structures with simple, uniform blocks, much like building **something with LEGO bricks**.

In the context of machine learning or computer vision tasks such as object detection or segmentation in 3D space, voxels **are used to discretize the continuous 3D space into manageable units**. This is similar to how an image is divided into pixels for processing. Each voxel might contain various information such as color, depth information from Lidar sensors, or any other type of sensor reading that provides spatially distributed measurements.
